entity.description: A Malaysian Airlines passenger plane designated Flight 17.

actuality.verbatim: Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 (MH17) was shot from the sky over eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 passengers and crew members.
actuality.normalized: Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 (MH17) was shot from the sky over eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 passengers and crew members.
actuality.outcome: Total loss of life and aircraft

actuality.verbatim: a Buk antiaircraft missile was launched from separatist-controlled territory, likely hoping to hit a Ukrainian aircraft rather than a passenger jet.
actuality.normalized: Separatists launched a Buk antiaircraft missile from separatist-controlled territory, intending to hit a Ukrainian aircraft but instead hit a passenger jet.

actuality.verbatim: Over the past three years, thanks to a wealth of openly accessible and verifiable information, we have been able to determine precisely how that Buk missile launcher reached a field in eastern Ukraine.
actuality.normalized: Over the past three years, investigators used openly accessible and verifiable information to determine precisely how that Buk missile launcher reached a field in eastern Ukraine.
actuality.outcome: Full route of Buk launcher established

actuality.verbatim: We know who organized the transport of the weapon in Ukraine, where the missile launcher came from before it arrived in Ukraine, and even the small dents and remaining traces of painted marks on the Buk that reveal its identity, going back to 2010.
actuality.normalized: Investigators identified the organizers of the weapon's transport in Ukraine, the missile launcher's origin before Ukraine, and the painted marks on the Buk that trace its identity back to 2010.
actuality.outcome: Full origin and identity of Buk launcher established

actuality.verbatim: This report will serve as a survey of the information related to the downing of MH17 that is freely available for anyone with an internet connection to access, analyze, and verifyâ€”in other words, open source information.
actuality.normalized: This report surveys freely available open-source information about the downing of MH17 for public access, analysis, and verification.

actuality.verbatim: Some of these counter-narratives were created and promoted by the Russian Federation, while others are almost exclusively found online.
actuality.normalized: The Russian Federation created and promoted some counter-narratives about MH17, while others circulate only online.

actuality.verbatim: Ukraine retook the city of Sloviansk on July 5, which had been seized by the separatist commander Igor Strelkov Girkin.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian Forces recaptured Sloviansk on July 5 from separatist commander Igor Strelkov Girkin.

actuality.verbatim: The recently-formed forces of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic retreated to Donetsk after fleeing Sloviansk, Kramatorsk, and other cities.
actuality.normalized: DNR forces retreated to Donetsk after abandoning Sloviansk, Kramatorsk, and other cities.

actuality.verbatim: Russian-led separatist forces destroyed numerous bridges and blocked strategic roads leading into and near Donetsk.
actuality.normalized: Russian-led separatist forces destroyed bridges and blocked strategic roads to hinder Ukrainian advance on Donetsk.

actuality.verbatim: On July 16, 2014, Russian Federation soldiers launched devastating artillery attacks against Ukrainian army positions near Amvrosiivka, Ukraine.
actuality.normalized: Russian Federation soldiers launched artillery attacks on Ukrainian positions near Amvrosiivka on July 16, 2014.

actuality.verbatim: These attacks were launched from multiple positions, including one inside Russia near Seleznev, approximately 750 meters from the Russia-Ukraine border.
actuality.normalized: Russian forces fired artillery from Seleznev, Russia, 750 meters from the Ukraine border.

actuality.verbatim: For the first time, the Russian military was launching documentable, direct artillery attacks from their own territory, with their own equipment, and with their own soldiers, against the Ukrainian military.
actuality.normalized: Russian military conducted documented artillery attacks from Russia using Russian equipment and soldiers against Ukraine.

entity.full_classification: Entity > MaterialEntity > PhysicalAsset > Vehicle > Aircraft > Transport
Entity > MaterialEntity > PhysicalAsset > Vehicle > Aircraft > Fighter

actuality.verbatim: On July 14, a Ukrainian AN-26 transport plane was shot down near the Russia-Ukraine border.
actuality.normalized: Separatists shot down a Ukrainian AN-26 transport plane near the Russia-Ukraine border on July 14.

actuality.verbatim: Two days later, a Ukrainian Su-25 ground attack jet was shot down south of Snizhne, and another was damaged.
actuality.normalized: Separatists shot down one Ukrainian Su-25 jet and damaged another south of Snizhne.

actuality.verbatim: Russiaâ€™s decision to provide a powerful Buk-M1 anti-aircraft missile system fits into the general course of events.
actuality.normalized: Russia provided a Buk-M1 anti-aircraft missile system to separatists to counter Ukrainian air offensives.

actuality.verbatim: The Russian Federation later provided additional anti-aircraft missile systems, including a Pantsir-S1, to Russian-led separatists.
actuality.normalized: Russia supplied Pantsir-S1 and other SAM systems to separatists, requiring significant training.

actuality.verbatim: For six hours before the downing of MH17, Ukrainians went online to discuss a Buk missile launcher slowly creeping through eastern Ukraine.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian civilians reported a Buk missile launcher moving through eastern Ukraine six hours before MH17 was shot down.

entity.description: Specific Buk missile launcher identified by JIT

entity.full_classification: Entity > MaterialEntity > PhysicalAsset > Vehicle > GroundVehicle > Truck

entity.description: Donetsk resident who tweeted Buk sighting
VK public group sharing Buk convoy details
French magazine that published Buk convoy photos

actuality.verbatim: Just after Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 left Amsterdam, this weapon was filmed heading south out of the Ukrainian, separatist-controlled town of Snizhne.
actuality.normalized: A Buk missile launcher was filmed leaving Snizhne southbound shortly after MH17 departed Amsterdam.

actuality.verbatim: This Buk missile launcher was hauled on a red trailer attached to a Volvo truck that had previously been stolen from a vehicle yard in Donetsk.
actuality.normalized: Separatists used a stolen Volvo truck and red trailer to haul Buk 332 from Donetsk.

actuality.verbatim: Over the past three years, Bellingcat has exhaustively analyzed these materials and confirmed their veracity.
actuality.normalized: Bellingcat verified the authenticity of Buk convoy photos and videos over three years.

actuality.verbatim: A Twitter user living in Donetsk tweeted at 10:11am local time describing an anti-aircraft missile system near Snizhne.
actuality.normalized: A Donetsk resident tweeted at 10:11am about a Buk missile launcher near Snizhne.

actuality.verbatim: The VK group Donetsk is Ukraine! shared a message at 9:15am detailing the Buk convoy composition and location.
actuality.normalized: VK group published convoy details including Volvo truck, Rav4, UAZ, and Hyundai escorting Buk through Donetsk.

actuality.verbatim: Paris Match published two screenshots showing Buk 332, the Volvo truck, red trailer, and grey Toyota Rav4 SUV shortly after the downing.
actuality.normalized: Paris Match released photos of Buk 332 on Volvo truck with Rav4 escort days after MH17 crash.

actuality.verbatim: A YouTube video uploaded on May 3, 2016, showed Buk 332 being hauled through Makiivka by the same Volvo truck and red trailer.
actuality.normalized: YouTube video revealed Buk 332 convoy route through Makiivka on July 17, 2014.

entity.description: Town east of Makiivka on H21 highway
Torez native who tweeted Buk sightings
City east of Snizhne toward Russian border

actuality.verbatim: This detour was likely taken to avoid a low-hanging bridge along the highway, which may have not been high enough for the vehicle hauling a Buk with mounted missiles.
actuality.normalized: Convoy detoured through Makiivka to bypass low bridge insufficient for Buk height.

actuality.verbatim: Stratfor published a satellite image showing the Buk convoy in Makiivka at 11:08am local time on July 17, 2014.
actuality.normalized: Stratfor satellite image captured Buk convoy in Makiivka minutes after video was filmed.

actuality.verbatim: A Twitter user created a YouTube account and uploaded a video geolocated to Zuhres showing the Buk convoy on H21 highway.
actuality.normalized: Twitter user uploaded geolocated video of Buk convoy on H21 highway in Zuhres.

actuality.verbatim: At 12:07pm, Twitter user @WowihaY reported a surface-to-air missile launcher passing through Torez toward Snizhne.
actuality.normalized: @WowihaY tweeted at 12:07pm that a Buk launcher was moving through Torez toward Snizhne.

actuality.verbatim: The Ukrainian Security Service published a composite photograph showing the Buk convoy in Zuhres and Torez.
actuality.normalized: SBU released composite photo matching Buk convoy in Zuhres and Torez locations.

actuality.verbatim: A photograph taken in Torez center showed the Volvo truck hauling the Buk with UAZ-469 jeep behind.
actuality.normalized: Witness photographed Buk 332 on Volvo truck with UAZ escort in Torez center.

actuality.verbatim: A Snizhne resident photographed the unloaded Buk moving through a residential area toward the launch field.
actuality.normalized: Local resident captured Buk 332 moving under own power toward launch site south of Snizhne.

actuality.verbatim: A Torez resident took a photograph showing the white trail of a missile launch from a field south of Snizhne shortly after hearing loud noises.
actuality.normalized: Torez resident photographed missile launch trail from field south of Snizhne after hearing explosions.

entity.description: Village south of Snizhne near launch field
Blogger who geolocated missile trail photo
Cyber-security firm that verified missile photo
Journalist who visited launch site with Miller

actuality.verbatim: @WowihaY shared the missile trail photograph on Twitter at 7:23pm local time, three hours after MH17 was downed.
actuality.normalized: @WowihaY tweeted missile launch photo at 19:23 local time, three hours after MH17 crash.
actuality.outcome: First public missile launch image shared

actuality.verbatim: Ukraine@War geolocated the missile trail photograph to a field east of Chervonyi Zhovten village.
actuality.normalized: Blogger Ukraine@War pinpointed launch site to field east of Chervonyi Zhovten.
actuality.outcome: Launch site geolocated to exact field

actuality.verbatim: The Dutch Safety Board and JIT confirmed the missile was fired from a field south of Snizhne at coordinates 47.973906, 38.763963.
actuality.normalized: DSB and JIT triangulated launch site to field south of Snizhne at precise coordinates.

actuality.verbatim: Fox-IT and NIDF experts verified the missile trail photograph showed no signs of manipulation or fraud.
actuality.normalized: Digital forensics firms Fox-IT and NIDF authenticated missile launch photograph as genuine.

actuality.verbatim: Journalists Miller and Oliphant found a burned field with weapons container debris from Steklo Plastik at the launch site on July 22, 2014.
actuality.normalized: Reporters discovered scorched field with Steklo Plastik weapons container fragments at launch site.

actuality.verbatim: A Chervonyi Zhovten resident saw and heard a missile launch from the field immediately before MH17 was downed.
actuality.normalized: Village resident witnessed missile launch from field and saw it strike plane.

actuality.verbatim: Satellite imagery showed the launch field was altered between July 16-21, 2014, with new track marks appearing.
actuality.normalized: Digital Globe satellite images revealed field disturbance and fresh vehicle tracks at launch site July 16-21.

actuality.verbatim: The Ukrainian Ministry of Interior published a video showing Buk 332 heading toward the Russian border in Luhansk on July 18, 2014.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian Interior Ministry released video of Buk 332 with three missiles driving toward Russia day after MH17 crash.

entity.description: Street in Luhansk where Buk was filmed
Donetsk construction company whose Volvo was stolen

actuality.verbatim: A Ukrainian policeman filmed Buk 332 from a safe-house in Luhansk at 12:18am on July 18, showing only three missiles remaining.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian police officer captured video of Buk 332 with one missile missing during retreat through Luhansk.
actuality.outcome: Buk retreat with missing missile documented

actuality.verbatim: The JIT determined Buk 332 traveled through Krasniy Luch, Debaltseve, and Luhansk before reaching Russia via telecommunications data.
actuality.normalized: JIT traced Buk retreat route through Krasniy Luch and Debaltseve to Luhansk using telecom intercepts.

actuality.verbatim: Intercepted phone calls revealed panicked separatists saying the Buk was taken across the Ukraine-Russia border in early hours of July 18.
actuality.normalized: JIT intercepted calls captured separatists stating Buk crossed into Russia before dawn July 18.

actuality.verbatim: Stroymekhanizatsiya's owner confirmed the Volvo truck hauling Buk 332 was stolen from his Donetsk yard by separatists.
actuality.normalized: Truck owner verified Volvo used to haul Buk was seized by separatists from his Donetsk base.

actuality.verbatim: Satellite imagery confirmed the Volvo low-loader was missing from Stroymekhanizatsiya yard at 11:08am on July 17, proving it was hauling the Buk.
actuality.normalized: Digital Globe satellite showed Volvo trailer absent from Donetsk yard during Buk transport, confirming theft timeline.

actuality.verbatim: The three escort vehicles (VW van, Toyota RAV4, UAZ-469) were part of a July 15 convoy that transported tanks and howitzers along the same route.
actuality.normalized: Escort vehicles previously moved military equipment along identical route on July 15, proving separatist control.
actuality.outcome: Route security established prior to Buk movement

actuality.verbatim: Satellite and witness evidence confirm the same three escort vehicles traveled the identical route on July 15 and 17, proving separatist control.
actuality.normalized: Matching vehicle convoy on July 15 and 17 demonstrated established separatist control over Buk transport route.

entity.description: Russian military unit that transported Buk 332
Russian city where Buk 332 convoy originated
Russian town near Ukraine border where convoy was last seen
Temporary designation for Buk 332 before full number was determined
Russian military unit responsible for transporting Buk 332
Missile launcher replaced by Buk 332 in convoy

actuality.verbatim: Bellingcat identified distinctive markings on Buk 332 including obscured chassis numbers, damaged rubber side skirt, and white symbols that matched between Russia and Ukraine.
actuality.normalized: Bellingcat matched unique identifiers on Buk 332 between June convoy in Russia and July deployment in Ukraine.
actuality.outcome: Buk positively identified as Russian military asset

actuality.verbatim: Bellingcat used rubber side skirt damage patterns as unique fingerprints to positively identify Buk 332 between Russia and Ukraine.
actuality.normalized: Side skirt damage analysis provided conclusive identification matching Buk 332 between Russian convoy and Ukrainian deployment.

actuality.verbatim: The 53rd Brigade convoy including Buk 332 traveled from Kursk to Millerovo near Ukraine border on June 23-25, 2014.
actuality.normalized: Russian 53rd Brigade transported Buk 332 from Kursk base to Millerovo staging area June 23-25.
actuality.outcome: Buk positioned near border before MH17

actuality.verbatim: Bellingcat determined 2nd Battalion of 53rd Brigade transported Buk 332 as replacement for missing Buk 222, despite 332 being assigned to 3rd Battalion.
actuality.normalized: 2nd Battalion moved Buk 332 to border as substitute for absent Buk 222, establishing unit responsibility.
actuality.outcome: Specific military unit identified as responsible

actuality.verbatim: Bellingcat identified over 200 soldiers' social media profiles from 53rd Brigade, confirming many members' involvement in the June convoy that transported Buk 332.
actuality.normalized: Social media analysis identified 200+ 53rd Brigade soldiers, confirming personnel involved in Buk 332 transport convoy.
actuality.outcome: Individual personnel involved in transport identified

actuality.verbatim: Russian Buk 332 of the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade shot down MH17 on July 17, 2014 after firing from a field south of Snizhne.
actuality.normalized: Evidence proves Russian 53rd Brigade's Buk 332 launched missile that destroyed MH17 from separatist-controlled territory.

entity.description: Commander of Russia's 53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade
Russian intelligence chief for Girkin's separatist forces, key figure in Buk transport
Kremlin aide who met with Dubinsky
Ukrainian-controlled city falsely claimed by Russia as video location

actuality.verbatim: Bellingcat provided uncensored report identifying 53rd Brigade command structure and individuals with decision-making power over Buk 332 to Dutch JIT.
actuality.normalized: Bellingcat supplied Dutch investigators with detailed report on 53rd Brigade leadership involved in Buk 332 deployment to Ukraine.

actuality.verbatim: SBU published intercepted calls showing Sergey Dubinsky organizing Buk transport through separatist territory under call-sign Khmury and pseudonym Petrovsky.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian intelligence intercepted communications proving Dubinsky coordinated Buk missile launcher movement through Donbas.
actuality.outcome: Key organizer of Buk transport identified

actuality.verbatim: Novaya Gazeta investigation with Swedish audio experts confirmed Dubinsky's voice on intercepted calls discussing Buk transport logistics.
actuality.normalized: Independent media and forensic experts verified Dubinsky's voice coordinating Buk missile launcher convoy operations.
actuality.outcome: Voice identification confirmed by independent experts

actuality.verbatim: Russian MoD falsely claimed July 18 Luhansk Buk video was filmed in government-controlled Krasnoarmeysk using fabricated billboard evidence.
actuality.normalized: Russian Defense Ministry fabricated evidence claiming Buk retreat video was shot in Ukrainian-controlled territory, not separatist Luhansk.

actuality.verbatim: Russian MoD presented falsified flight path map claiming MH17 deviated significantly from course before being shot down.
actuality.normalized: Russian Defense Ministry fabricated flight path data suggesting Ukrainian air traffic controllers deliberately redirected MH17 into danger zone.
actuality.outcome: False deviation claim promoted Ukrainian guilt narrative

entity.description: Investigated MH17 flight path and debunked Russian deviation claims
Russian Air Force Chief of Staff who presented fabricated radar data
Former air accident investigator who debunked Russian radar claims
Village where Russia falsely claimed Ukrainian Buks were deployed
American scientific organization that analyzed Russian satellite images
Researcher at Middlebury Institute who analyzed fabricated Russian satellite imagery

entity.primary_reference: James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies
entity.description: Research center that conducted forensic analysis of Russian satellite imagery

actuality.verbatim: Dutch Safety Board report Section 2.1 debunked Russian MoD claims that MH17 significantly deviated from flight path before being shot down.
actuality.normalized: DSB investigation proved MH17 maintained straight course and did not change path as falsely claimed by Russian Defense Ministry.

actuality.verbatim: Multiple radar experts confirmed Russian MoD fabricated radar data claiming Ukrainian Su-25 fighter jet was near MH17 when it was actually falling debris.
actuality.normalized: Independent radar experts proved Russian radar data showing Ukrainian fighter was fabricated and actually depicted MH17 wreckage falling.
actuality.outcome: Russian fighter jet narrative definitively debunked

actuality.verbatim: AAAS forensic analysis found Russian MoD satellite images had incorrect shadow angles proving they were misdated and fabricated.
actuality.normalized: American scientific association determined Russian satellite imagery shadows didn't match claimed dates, proving deliberate fabrication.
actuality.outcome: Scientific proof of satellite image manipulation

actuality.verbatim: Jeffrey Lewis and Middlebury Institute used TungstÃ¨ne forensic tool to confirm Russian satellite images showed May vegetation patterns, not July.
actuality.normalized: Middlebury researchers using French defense software proved Russian satellite images actually showed May conditions, proving fabrication.

participants.subject_reference: James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies

actuality.outcome: Forensic proof images were months old

actuality.verbatim: Russian MoD claimed Ukrainian Buks traveled 70km in 24 minutes to Zaroshchenske, requiring impossible 150+ km/h speed through separatist territory.
actuality.normalized: Russian Defense Ministry fabricated timeline claiming Ukrainian Buks moved to launch site at physically impossible speed through hostile territory.

entity.description: Russian state-funded television channel that aired fabricated satellite image
Russian TV host who presented fake satellite image on Channel One
Russian state news agency that spread fabricated satellite image story
Head of Almaz-Antey who made false claims about missile types
Russian town near Ukraine border where 9M38M1 missiles were photographed
Older Buk missile type that Russia claimed was no longer in service
Newer Buk missile type that Almaz-Antey claimed was used
Russian newspaper that investigated Zaroshchenske claims
German investigative group that interviewed Zaroshchenske witnesses

actuality.verbatim: Middlebury Institute forensic analysis confirmed Russian satellite images were heavily manipulated with digitally added Buk missile launchers.
actuality.normalized: Jeffrey Lewis team proved Russian MoD satellite images showed digitally inserted Buk launchers using forensic software analysis.
actuality.outcome: Scientific proof of digital image manipulation

actuality.verbatim: Channel One Russia aired fabricated satellite image showing fighter jet shooting down MH17, later proven to be from online message board.
actuality.normalized: Russian state television presented fake satellite image of fighter attacking MH17 that originated from internet forum post.
actuality.outcome: Blatant fabrication exposed as internet hoax

actuality.verbatim: Almaz-Antey falsely claimed 9M38M1 missiles were discontinued in 1999 while Reuters photos showed them in Russian service August 2014 near Ukraine border.
actuality.normalized: Russian arms manufacturer lied about discontinuing 9M38M1 missiles while photographic evidence proved they remained in active Russian military service.
actuality.outcome: Russian missile claims contradicted by photographic evidence

actuality.verbatim: Multiple international media organizations including BBC, NOS, and Correct!v found zero witnesses in Zaroshchenske who saw or heard missile launch.
actuality.normalized: International journalists interviewed Zaroshchenske residents and found complete absence of witness testimony supporting Russian launch site claims.
actuality.outcome: Complete absence of witness testimony for alleged launch site

actuality.verbatim: JIT intercepted call captured separatists confirming Zaroshchenske was not under Ukrainian control and no missile launch occurred there.
actuality.normalized: Dutch investigators recorded separatist fighters admitting Zaroshchenske was pro-Russian territory with no missile activity on July 17.
actuality.outcome: Separatist control of alleged launch site confirmed

entity.description: Ukrainian missile launcher falsely accused of downing MH17
Location where Ukrainian Buk 312 was filmed on March 19, 2014
Destination where Ukrainian Buk 312 was transported in March 2014
Location 130km northwest of MH17 crash site where Ukrainian Buks were filmed
Poltava Oblast base where Ukrainian Buks were photographed in July 2014
Ukrainian unit whose Buk movements were documented on video

actuality.verbatim: SBU mistakenly showed Ukrainian Buk 312 from March 2014 evacuation, leading to false accusations it was involved in MH17 downing.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian intelligence agency error in presenting outdated Buk 312 footage created false narrative about Ukrainian involvement.

actuality.verbatim: Ukrainian Military TV footage from Dovhenke base 130km from crash site was misrepresented as evidence of Ukrainian Buk near MH17.
actuality.normalized: Ukrainian military television segment filmed far from crash site was falsely used to claim Ukrainian Buks were in launch position.
actuality.outcome: Geolocation proved footage was irrelevant to MH17

actuality.verbatim: Open source evidence conclusively proves Russian 53rd Brigade's Buk 332 transported from Russia, launched missile from Snizhne field, killing 298 people, then retreated to Russia.
actuality.normalized: Comprehensive open source investigation establishes Russian military responsibility for MH17 downing beyond reasonable doubt.
